The titles published in this series are listed at 
he reign of Peter the Great (1672-1725) was marked by an unprecedented wave of 
reform in Russia. This book provides an innovative reappraisal of the Petrine 
Age, in which hitherto neglected aspects of the tsar's transformation of his 
country are studied. More specifically, the reforms enacted by the tsar are 
assessed in light of the religious notion of instauration - a belief in the 
restoration of Adamic knowledge in the last age - and a historical and cultural 
analysis of the impact of Western esotericism at the Russian court. This book 
will appeal to scholars of Russian history and religion, as well as being of 
wider interest to those studying Western esotericism in Early Modern and 
eighteenth-century Europe.
